svcproc.title: FLOW CONTROL AND RELIEF VALVE
svcproc.para: Maximum flow to the operating circuit and maximum system pressure are determined by the integral flow control and relief valve in a special outlet cover used on some V10 and V20 series pumps. This feature is shown in Figure 6. An orifice in the cover limits maximum flow (View A, Figure 6). A pilot-operated type relief shifts to divert excess fluid delivery to the tank, thus limiting system pressure to a prescribed maximum.

svcproc.para: View A of Figure 6 shows the condition when the total pump delivery can be passed through the orifice. This condition usually occurs only at low drive speeds.The large spring chamber is connected to the pressure port through an orifice. Pressure in this chamber equalizes pressure at the other end of the relief valve spool and the light spring holds the spool closed. Pump delivery is blocked from the tank port by the spool land.

When the pump delivery is more than the flow rate determined by the orifice plug, a pressure build-up forces the spool open against the light spring. Excess fluid is throttled past the spool to the tank port as shown in View B, Figure 6.

If pressure in the system builds up to the relief valve setting, (View C, Figure 6), the pilot ppet is forced off its seat. Fluid in the large spring chamber flows through the spool and out to the tank. This flow through the small sensing orifice causes a pressure drop and prevents pressure in the large spring area from increasing beyond the relief valve setting. As pressure against the right end of the spool starts to exceed the relief valve setting, the pressure differential forces the spool to the left, against the light spring, porting the full pump flow to the tank.
